WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN FARMERS EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Ellen Florence Snook
Address: 26 Eastwood
Birthplace: North Dakota, North Dakota, U.S.A.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in eastern Canada? 1907
Where did you set up housekeeping? In the Westmoreland district
Where had you been living before that? In Nebraska
For how many people did you prepare meals? Three
How far was it to your nearest store? 4 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Twice yearly
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour Sugar Beans Rolled Oats Tea Coffee Syrup Rumors and also dried peaches B. Powder B. Soda

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Four Roses
In what quantities did you buy it? Normally 6 or 7 sacks each
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? Around 175¢
How much did you use Graham flour?
Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? Yes No Far away? What year? 1877 or 1878
That was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 30¢
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? Yes Whole wheat? Yes Farina? Yes
Other? Wheat Grass, sometimes called Red Wheat
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it?

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 10 oz. 20 lb. packs
At what price?

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? By milking cows
Butter? Churning. Cream. Eggs? Night cream
What was the price of butter? 15c. 20c. 25c. 30c. 35c. 40c.
Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes. How? Cured in salt and stand in boxes
Did you make butter? Yes. Cheese? Yes
What kind of cheese? Skim milk and Cottage

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Beef. Pork. Fish
Prairie chickens. Turkey
How did you get fresh meat? By killing our own animal
How often did you get fresh meat? Only in winter when it could be kept frozen
How did you preserve meat? By canning. Salting. Smoking. Storing in head
Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No
If so what year was it organized?
Did you use game? Yes. What kinds?
For how long?
What part did fish play in the family diet? In winter
Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh. Frozen

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

In Oct. 1907 Husband self & Both children each owning the age from 21 to 24 years. Breakfast - Porridge, toast, one egg each and strong coffee. Dinner Potatoes vegetable if any on hand must Bread & Butter Soup or something for desert. Supper Warm potatoes Cold meat - Coffee Bread & butter fruit.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

I can not say you would call it starvation but with sugar, eggs, and being paid out some times it was pretty hard going and with one of my family schemes was in the hospital most of the time for nearly 15 years and then hospitalization came to help with situations times even though during the second world war and in 1937 our medals were mostly potatoes Bread tea and fruit which was used sparingly as sugar was too high in price and hard to get. Meat was scarce as the crops and food was frozen and we were forced to sell our stock which took form as both milk & Butter most people got relief but we did not. My husband & children and my self managed with out as we knew it would all have to be charged back. I have always tried to raise our own potatoes & vegetables but some years they were not very many as in fruit we were fortunate enough to get Saskatoons.

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

I find in these days people are not satisfied with what I would say good substantial foods but want more fancy articles, pickles of all kinds, jellies, pies, rich cakes, pastries of different kinds, and without these foods the meal does not seem complete.
